ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Polyaniline nanostructures expedient as working electrode materials in supercapacitors

Affiliation.OrgDivision: School of Engineering Sciences and Technology

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Granular type polyaniline (PANi), PANi nanofibers (NFs), and PANi nanotubes (NTs) expedient as working electrode materials for supercapacitors are synthesized. The synthesis procedure used in this work facilitates not only the synthesis of solid powders of the PANi nanostructures, but also thin films constituted by the same PANi nanostructures in the same experiment. PANi NFs are found to exhibit faster electrode kinetics and better capacitance when compared to PANi NTs and granular PANi. Specific capacitance and energy storage per unit mass of PANi NFs are 239.47 Fg−1 (at 0.5 Ag−1) and 43.2 Wh kg−1, respectively. Electrical conductivity of PANi NFs is also better when compared to the other two nanostructures. Properties of the three PANi nanostructures are explicated in correlation with crystallinity, intrinsic oxidation state, doping degree, BET surface area, and ordered mesoporosity pertaining to the nanostructures.

ArticleNote.Heading: Electronic Supplementary Material

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Among the conducting polymers, polyaniline (PANi) was found to be the most promising one [1–4] for various applications owing to its ease of synthesis, tunable oxidation state, and stability; moreover, PANi’s monomer (i.e. aniline) is of low cost. By varying the oxidation of aniline during polymerization, PANi can be synthesized in a wide variety of nanostructures [5–10], which are found to possess properties suitable for their application in organic electronics that include field effect transistors, chemical sensors, and supercapacitors [11–17]. Anisotropic growth [18–24] of PANi into tubular and fiber type nanostructures can be achieved by electrospinning, template-guided methods, and lithographic techniques. However, large scale production of PANi with controlled morphologies and sizes, which can result in desired properties, is still a challenge. Moreover, in order to use them as working electrode materials in electrochemical applications, it has been found that they have to possess characteristics namely high surface area, high ordered crystallinity, suitable oxidation state and doping degree, and ordered micro to mesoporosity. In view of the above mentioned aspects, there is an obvious necessity to generate suitable synthesis procedures that not only result in nanostructures with the required characteristics, but are easy to execute.

At present, fortunately there are convenient synthesis procedures that have connoted positive results. For an exemplary example: A polymeric stabilizer was used to facilitate a satiric effect in PANi chain growth that allowed morphology modification of the resultant PANi nanostructures useful for electrochemical applications [24]. In recent reviews, synthesis and properties of PANi nanostructures (both modified and unmodified forms) have been elaborately discussed [25–28]. A careful observation shows that specific capacitance values of different PANi nanostructures depend on the synthesis strategies, and it is difficult to correlate the enhancement in the electrochemical behavior of these nanostructures in general with properties like crystallinity, intrinsic oxidation state, doping degree, BET surface area, and ordered mesoporosity. However, there are few research works that could remove the above mentioned uncertainty (especially in terms of morphology) separately in the cases of polyaniline nanofibers (PANi NFs) [29–33] and polyaniline nanotubes (PANi NTs) [34, 35].

Keeping in view the above pointed out aspects, an easy and effective single step synthesis procedure that results in PANi nanostructures expedient as working electrode materials in supercapacitors is presented. By instigating miniscule variations in the conventional oxidative polymerization, different PANi nanostructures, namely granular type PANi, PANi NFs, and PANi NTs are synthesized. The measured electrochemical properties of the three PANi nanostructures are explicated in correlation with nanostructures’ crystallinity, intrinsic oxidation state, doping degree, BET surface area, and ordered mesoporosity. The synthesis procedure used in this work facilitates not only the synthesis of solid powders of PANi nanostructures, but also thin films constituted by the same PANi nanostructures in the same experiment. These thin films are being explored for gas sensing applications in a separate work. Moreover, the synthesis procedure used in this work also facilitates in-situ synthesis of composite materials (like carbon nanofibers/PANi NFs, carbon nanopipes/PANi NTs, etc.), which is otherwise not possible with other synthesis procedures that are available to synthesize PANi nanostructures. The importance of this work is in the comparison of specific capacitance values of granular type PANi, PANi NFs, and PANi NTs that are obtained using the same synthesis process except for miniscule variations in the concentration of the starting materials and mixing the reactants.

Section2.Heading: Synthesis
Section2.Para: Granular type PANi was synthesized by chemical oxidative polymerization (COP) [36]. COP of aniline is a traditional method for preparing PANi. Green colored PANi can be readily obtained after mixing aniline with an oxidizer/initiator in an acidic solution. Oxidation of aniline is exothermic and, therefore, the oxidizing agent is added slowly like in a titration procedure. In order to avoid any increase in temperature of the reaction mixture during the addition of oxidizing agent, the flask containing the reaction mixture will be normally placed in an ice bath. PANi prepared in this way is highly aggregated. In the rapid mixing polymerization [37, 38] method, PANi is obtained by mixing the oxidizer/initiator solution to the aniline solution all at once, and rapidly mixing the resultant solution. Rapidly-mixed reactions are normally more exothermic than slowly-mixed reactions; therefore, in rapid mixing polymerization, utmost care is taken to maintain the reaction mixtures at low temperatures typically in the range 0–4 ∘C.

The procedure for preparing PANi nanostructures (pertaining to this work) is discussed here. 250 ml of hydrochloric acid (1 M HCl) was taken in a round-bottom flask (1 L) equipped with a mechanical stirrer and a dropping funnel. 20 ml of vacuum distilled aniline was then added to it (and in the case of synthesizing a thin film, a standard microscope slide may be subsequently placed in the flask). The temperature of the solution was maintained in the range 0–4 ∘C using an ice bath. 1 M HCl aqueous ammonium peroxy disulfate (APS) solution placed in the dropping funnel was then added drop by drop to the aniline solution in the flask for 1 h (APS:Aniline amount is 1:4 molar ratio). However, a slight variation has been instigated here by allowing a quicker drop by drop addition in the anticipation of arresting secondary nucleation to some extent to end up with smaller sized aggregates (granular PANi). During the APS addition, the temperature of the reaction mixture was maintained in the range 0–4 ∘C. After the addition was complete, the reaction mixture was left stirring for 1 h. The suspension was filtered to obtain a wet cake (in the case of obtaining thin film: before filtering, the microscope slide was removed from the flask). The wet cake and microscope slide are subsequently washed with water, then with methanol, and finally with diethyl ether. Dark green colored wet cake and the microscope slide are then dried at 90 ∘C under vacuum for 48 h.

PANi NFs and PANi NTs are synthesized by the rapid mixing polymerization method. In the case of PANi NFs, the same procedure as described above was followed except for the drop wise mixing of APS; here, the polymerization was initiated by rapidly adding APS at once to the reaction mixture (HCl + aniline + microscope slide) to completely arrest any secondary nucleation that will in turn result in only 1D fibrous growth throughout the mixture. In the case of PANi NTs, the same procedure as in the case of PANi NFs was followed except for the use of 100 ml (instead of 250 ml) of aqueous 1 M HCl, 0.46 g of aniline and 0.56 g of APS. This miniscule instigation is to reduce the acidity of the reaction medium that in turn might result in tubular morphology [39]. In the case of PANi NTs, by adopting rapid mixing polymerization and low acidic reaction medium, the idea is to lock the tubular morphology throughout the reaction medium. Please see the section on Materials in Electronic Supplementary Material (ESM) for information on the chemicals.

Section2.Heading: Characterization and testing
Section2.Para: The field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) (Model Zeiss Ultra 55) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) (Model FEI Technai G2 S-Twin) are used to study the morphology of the synthesized materials. FESEM and TEM are operated at accelerating voltages of 5 and 200 kV, respectively. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns are recorded with 2θ (where θ is the angle of diffraction) values from 10 to 60∘ using Cu Kα as the x-ray source (λ=1.54 Å); Bruker’s AXS Model D8 Advance System was used to carry out the XRD experiments. Lorentzian fitting was used to obtain information namely areas under diffraction peaks and full width at half-maxima of peaks. Micro Raman spectroscopic study was carried out using a LabRam HR800 Raman spectrometer; 514.5 nm green line of an Ar+ ion laser was used as the excitation source. The spectral resolution of all the measurements was 1 cm−1. XRD and Raman scattering studies are carried out to understand the phase information pertaining to the samples. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out to understand different oxidation states and doping levels in different samples; this study was carried out using Omicron Nanotechnology GmbH, Germany (model ESCA+, Al Ka, 1486.8 eV) equipment. All spectra presented are charge balanced and energy referenced to C 1s at 284.6 eV.

The presence of pores in the samples was investigated using physical adsorption of N2 at liquid N2 temperature (77 K) on an automatic surface area and porosity analyzer (ASAP2010, Micromeritics). Prior to this measurement, each sample was vacuum-degassed at 200 ∘C for 5 h. Specific surface area of the samples was determined according to the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method in the relative pressure range of 0.01–0.2. The total pore volume was obtained from the volume of N2 adsorbed at a relative pressure of 0.99. Pore size distribution in each sample case was obtained using the Barret—Joyner–Halenda (BJH) equation.

In order to evaluate the electrical conductivity of the samples, pellets with dimensions of 10×10×1 mm are prepared. The standard four probe method was used to measure the electrical conductivity (which was calculated using the formula
$4.532 \times t ( \frac{V}{i} )$ where V is the voltage, i is the applied current, and t is thickness of the sample). Keithley 6221 dc and ac power sources and Keithley 2182A nano voltmeter with Lakeshore 325 temperature controller are used to carry out these measurements. Electrochemical measurements are performed using a Potentiostat (Autolab Model PGSTAT 30). These measurements are made in a three electrode configuration at room temperature in the potential window −0.6 to 0.6 V with Ag/AgCl (saturated) as the reference electrode and platinum wire as the counter electrode in a 1 M aqueous H2SO4 electrolyte solution. Galvanostatic charge/discharge behavior was recorded at constant current density of 0.5 Ag−1. Prior to the measurement, the working electrode was prepared by drop casting nafion-impregnated sample onto a Glassy Carbon Electrode (GCE) surface. The active materials (granular PANi, PANi NFs, and PANi NTs) are separately dispersed in nafion solution (50 μl of 5 wt.% nafion is mixed in 10 ml ethanol (2 mg/ml)) and sonicated for 30 min to obtain a uniform suspension. 10 μl of this suspension was dropped onto a GCE (3 mm in diameter) surface and dried at 35 ∘C under air current.

Specific capacitance C
S was calculated (from cycle voltammetry) using the equation
$C_{S} = \frac{1}{V ( V_{i} - V_{f} )}\int_{V_{i}}^{V_{f}} I ( V ) \,dV$ where V is the potential scan rate (expressed in units of mV/s), the term V
i −V
f represents the sweep potential range and I(V) denotes the response current density (given in units of A/g). The specific capacitance (C sp) based on the galvanostat is calculated using the equation
$C_{\mathrm{sp}} = \frac{i \times \Delta t}{\Delta E \times m}$ where i is the discharge current (A), Δt is discharge time (s), ΔE is the voltage difference (V), and m is the active mass of the electrode material. The maximum storage energy E per unit was calculated using the equation
$E = \frac{1}{2}C_{\mathrm{sp}}V_{i}^{2}$ (where V
i is the initial voltage 0.6 V).

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
The green color of the synthesized materials (namely granular PANi, PANi NFs, and PANi NTs) is a strong indication of the presence of PANi in emeraldine salt state. Secondary electron plane view micrographs of the powders consisting granular PANi, PANi NFs, and PANi NTs are shown in Figs. 1(a), 1(b), and 1(c), respectively; plane view transmission electron micrographs of the same are shown in Fig. 2. The electron micrographs shown in Figs. 1(a) and 2(a) reveal the existence of highly agglomerated granular morphology; the particulate sizes are in the submicron range. This is due to the existence of large proportion of solution polymerized PANi in the agglomerated form [36]. Here, the polymerization of aniline is initiated with the formation of PANi nuclei, which are homogeneously distributed in the acidic solution. In the subsequent stage, as APS addition continued to take place, heterogeneous secondary growth of PANi has resulted on the already formed nuclei. When this secondary growth was almost arrested by rapid addition and mixing of APS, as anticipated, PANi NFs have formed. These are shown in Figs. 1(b) and 2(b). It is clear from the electron micrographs that PANi NFs possess relatively uniform sizes throughout the sample with diameters around 20–30 nm and length in the submicron range. Similarly, as anticipated, Figs. 1(c) and 2(c) depict the formation of several μm long PANi NTs with an external diameter of 200–300 nm and internal diameter of 50–100 nm. However, in this case, there is variation in aspect ratios as shown in Fig. S1 (ESM).
Fig. 1
Plane view field emission scanning electron micrographs of (a) granular PANi (used with permission [36]), (b) PANi nanofibers and (c) PANi nanotubes
Fig. 2
Plane view transmission electron micrographs of (a) granular PANi (used with permission [36]), (b) PANi nanofibers, and (c) PANi nanotubes

It is noteworthy to mention here that similar fibrous and tubular morphology is also observed in the case of each thin film on the microscope slide (Fig. S2 in ESM). This shows that the presence of microscope slide does not influence the polymerization of aniline and also the formation of different morphologies. This observation (nucleation and growth of PANi unaffected by the presence of any additional structures) was also used to synthesize different hybrid materials namely PANi coated carbon nanopipes and PANi coated graphene nanosheets and different composites namely PANi coated carbon nanofibers/PANi NFs, PANi coated carbon nanotubes/PANi NTs composite, PANi coated graphene nanosheets/PANi NFs, etc. Moreover, the synthesis procedure has allowed obtaining thin films with the above mentioned morphologies even on substrates like cleaned regular cotton cloth and plastic sheet (see Figs. S3–S5 in ESM), which can be used as flexible working electrodes.

Figure 3 shows x-ray photoelectron spectra obtained from different PANi nanostructures. The spectra (of all the PANi nanostructures) exhibit three major peaks at 532, 400, and 285 eV, corresponding to O 1s, N 1s, and C 1s photoemission, respectively. C and N are derived from the backbone of PANi. Two minor peaks at 169 and 199 eV correspond to S 2p and Cl 2p photoemission [40], respectively. S is from the oxidizer that was used for polymerizing the aniline to PANi. Cl is from HCl that was used during the synthesis of PANi nanostructures. Variation in the atomic percentages of these elements in the three cases under consideration are tabulated in Table S1 (ESM). The photoemission peaks corresponding to N 1s core-level shown in Fig. 3(b) are broad indicative of the existence of different bond structures. The best curve fit shows that each broad peak can be reasonably considered as a peak constituted by four Gaussian–Lorentzian peaks centered at ∼398.74, ∼399.73, ∼401.6, and ∼402.64 eV attributed to neutral and imine-like =N− structure, neutral and amine-like nitrogen atoms −NH−, cationic nitrogen atoms on the polymer backbone compensated with
$\mathrm{SO}_{4}^{2-}$ counter ions (these arise due to protonation of amine units) and protonated amine units, respectively. In the case of granular PANi, ∼401.6 eV peak is not prominent indicating less protonation of amine units during polymerization.
Fig. 3
(a) Survey x-ray photoelectron spectra of different samples namely granular PANi, PANi nanofibers, and PANi nanotubes, (b) N 1s core-level spectra of different PANi nanostructures, and (c) C 1s core-level spectra of different PANi nanostructures

The ratio of areas under =N– and –NH– components gives the quantitative intrinsic oxidation state [41, 42] of PANi. Ratio between the area under ∼402.6 eV peak and the total area under N 1s peaks is indicative of doping degree [43]. Quantitative data about intrinsic oxidation state and doping level in different PANi nanostructures under study are tabulated in Table 1. It is obvious from Table 1 that among the three PANi nanostructures, PANi NFs show the highest intrinsic oxidation state for PANi in them and highest doping degree. The photoemission peaks corresponding to C 1s core-level in the three PANi nanostructures are shown in Fig. 3(c). It is clear from the graphs that all of the C 1s spectra are asymmetric indicative of the presence of structural defects in the nanostructures. The deconvoluted Gaussian–Lorentzian peaks centered at ∼284.44, ∼285.57, and ∼287.75 eV are shown in Fig. 3(c). The difference in the binding energies for the two peaks with lower binding energies (i.e., ∼284.44 and ∼285.57 eV) is 1.0 eV, which is equal to the energy difference between C–H– and C–N. The peak centered at ∼287.75 eV is attributed to the C atoms associated with C–O single bond or C atoms linked to the positively charged N atoms [44]. The ratio of areas under ∼284.44 and ∼285.57 eV peaks represents the density of carbonyl defects [45]. Lesser this value better the structural integrity/stability of the corresponding structures. From Table 1, it is thus evident that PANi NFs are structurally the most stable ones when compared to granular PANi and PANi NTs. All in all, XPS analysis clearly indicates that PANi NFs (owing to high intrinsic oxidation, high doping degree and low defect density) would exhibit better electrical and electrochemical properties in comparison to granular PANi and PANi NTs.

Raman spectra obtained from granular PANi, PANi NFs, and PANi NTs are shown in Fig. 4. The typical bands of C–H bending of the quinoid/benzenoid ring, a weak C–N stretching, C=N stretching of the quinoid ring and C–C stretching of the benzenoid rings, which are characteristic bands of the basic PANi polymeric back bone structure [46] are detected in the case of all the three PANi nanostructures. The characteristic Raman bands and the respective attributions are tabulated in Table 2. However, in the case of PANi NFs and PANi NTs, intensities of C=N stretching mode of quinoid and C–H stretching of quinoid/benzenoid rings are more intense than the respective Raman modes obtained from granular PANi. Also, these bands are shifted to lower wave numbers side when compared towards the same bands obtained from granular PANi indicating structural difference. This complements well with the XPS results pertaining to PANi NFs and PANi NTs.
Fig. 4
Raman spectra obtained from (a) granular PANi, (b) PANi nanofibers, and (c) PANi nanotubes

Figure 5 shows x-ray diffractograms obtained from granular PANi, PANi NFs, and PANi NTs. Three noticeable diffraction peaks (centered at 2θ=∼15, ∼20, and ∼26∘) related to the presence of PANi [24, 37, 38, 47] are there in all the three cases. Two broad peaks centered at 2θ=20.4 and 26∘ in the case of PANi NFs and PANi NTs indicate partial crystallinity of PANi constituting these nanostructures. However, in the case of granular PANi, crystallinity is even poor. The diffraction peak at 2θ=20.4∘ is attributed to periodicity parallel to the polymer chain, while the other two diffraction peaks mentioned above are attributed to the periodicity perpendicular to the polymer chain. It is also noteworthy to mention the gradual change in the intensity of ∼26∘ peak. Typically, the nonconductive PANi emeraldine base does not have any observable peak at 2θ=∼26∘; however, here it is clearly visible that ∼26∘ peak gradually emerges in intensity with increase in protonation of the imine nitrogen. Careful analysis (after curve fitting) of the diffraction peak at 2θ=∼26∘ shows that the area under this peak and intensity of this peak are increasing in the order granular PANi < PANi NTs < PANi NFs, which is evidence of increasing structural ordering perpendicular to the polymer chain and enhanced charge carrier transport in the same order through the elongation of the effective conjugation length, respectively. From this analysis, too, it is evident that PANi NFs should perform better (electrically and electrochemically) than the other two nanostructures owing to its superior crystalline structure (highly ordered systems can display a metallic conductive state).
Fig. 5
X-ray diffractograms obtained from (a) granular PANi, (b) PANi nanofibers, and (c) PANi nanotubes

The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions pertaining to the three PANi nanostructures under study are shown in Fig. 6 and Fig. 7, respectively. The isotherms are characteristic of a combination of type I and type II isotherms. The type I isotherm features due to prominent adsorption below the relative pressure of P/P 0=0.1, which is due to the micropore filling or monolayer adsorption due to strong adsorbent-adsorbate interactions [48]. In the high relative pressure region (P/P 0>0.9), the isotherm is characteristic of multilayer adsorption on a macroporous solid [49]. The BET specific surface area was calculated as ∼29.75, ∼32.78, and ∼38.78 m2/g for granular PANi, PANi NTs, and PANI NFs, respectively. BJH adsorption average pore diameter was estimated as 52.5, 36.5, and 31.5 nm for granular PANi, PANi NTs, and PANi NFs respectively. Moreover, Fig. 7 clearly shows that granular PANi, PANi NTs, and PANi NFs possess ordered micropores to macropores with varying pore volume distribution. It is also noteworthy to observe higher micropores volume in the case of PANi NFs when compared to granular PANi and PANi NTs.
Fig. 6
Nitrogen adsorption isotherms of different samples namely granular PANi, PANi nanofibers, and PANi nanotubes
Fig. 7
Pore volume vs. pore diameter of (a) granular PANi, (b) PANi nanotubes, and (c) PANi nanofibers

Electrical conductivity values of the three PANi nanostructures considered in this work are shown in Fig. 8. It is clear from the observed conductivity values that all the PANi nanostructures show semiconducting type conductivity. The conductivity of the all the PANi nanostructures is also observed to increase with increase in temperature. The conductivity is in the order: PANi NFs > PANi NTs > granular PANi. Enhanced electrical conductivity of PANi has been elaborately explained in correlation with increase in intrinsic oxidation state of PANi constituting the nanostructures, crystallinity of PANi and doping degree in PANi [12]. In the present work, PANi NFs are exhibiting higher electrical conductivity owing to higher intrinsic oxidation state, degree of crystallinity, and doping degree of PANi constituting PANi NFs when compared to granular PANi and PANi NTs.
Fig. 8
Temperature dependent electrical conductivity of different samples namely granular PANi, PANi nanofibers and PANi nanotubes

Figure 9 shows cyclic voltammetry (CV) results obtained for different PANi nanostructures. PANi (owing to its ability to show pseudo capacitance) will typically exhibit two couples of redox peaks in the CV curve, in which the first pair of redox peaks (typically called C1/A1) are attributed to the redox transition of PANi from leucoemeraldine (semiconducting state) to polaronic emeraldine (conducting sate) while the second pair of redox peaks (typically called C2/A2) are due to the transformation from emeraldine to pernigraniline [50]. CV curves of granular PANi, PANi NTs, and PANi NFs follow a similar trend giving an indication of good protonation oxidative state (emeraldine salt). Another common observation for the three PANi nanostructures is the asymmetric shape of CV curves suggesting pseudo capacitance behavior for all. Pseudo capacitance is a phenomenon which obeys the faradaic charge-storage and depends mainly on surface area of the working electrode material (larger the surface area higher is the capacitance). Moreover, porous electrodes are preferable for capacitors because porosity not only increases the effective surface area, but also facilitates easy charge transportation (ordered pores and suitable arrangement of micro and mesopores provide the pathway for transporting charges) [51]. In the present study, the above made observations (with regard to surface area and pores distribution) show that PANi NTs and PANi NFs should provide enhanced electrode/electrolyte interface areas and facilitate the electrochemical accessibility of electrolyte through them when used electrode materials.
Fig. 9
CV analysis of different PANi nanostructures performed in a 1 M H2SO4. (a) Cyclic Voltagrams of electrodes consisting of PANi nanostructures at the same scan rate (20 mV s−1), (b) specific capacitance vs. scan rate of PANi nanostructures [(i) granular PANi, (ii) PANi nanotubes, and (iii) PANi nanofibers], (c) plots of the peak potential (the anodic peak potential, E pa and the cathodic peak potential, E pc) vs. the scan rate, and (d) plots of the peak current (the anodic peak current, I pa; the cathodic peak current, I pc) vs. the scan rate

C
S values calculated (at different scan rates) from CV curves are shown in Fig. 9(b). C
S values of granular PANi, PANi NTs, and PANi NFs (at 20 mVS−1) are 24.3, 123.5, and 148.2 Fg−1, respectively. As anticipated, PANi NFs show better capacitance. For convenience, CV curves obtained at different scan rates pertaining to the three samples are provided in Fig. S6 (ESM). Further analysis shows that the peak currents are varying linearly with respect to the scan rate for all the three samples indicating a reduced ionic diffusion path (that is, ionic motion is easily facilitated inside of the electrode) and improved utilization of the electrode material. Among the three samples, PANi NFs, however, show better CV characteristics.

Figure 10 illustrates galvanostatic first charge/discharge behavior (at constant current density of 0.5 Ag−1) of the three samples under study. Full charge/discharge behavior is given in Fig. S7 (ESM). Triangular-shaped (almost symmetric) charge/discharge curves indicate capacitive behavior of all the three electrode materials. Moreover, the deviation in linearity is typical of a pseudo capacitive contribution (as discussed above). The discharge time follows the order PANi NFs > PANi NTs > granular PANi. Galvanostat based C sp values pertaining to granular PANi, PANi NTs, and PANi NFs are 15.87, 146.92, and 239.47 Fg−1, respectively. The values measured in the case of PANi NTs and PANi NFs are superior than those exhibited by several recently reported PANi nanostructures (nanospheres and nanorods) [19] including nanofibers [19, 52, 53] obtained by different synthesis routes. The maximum storage energy per unit mass, E values for granular PANi, PANi NTs, and PANi NFs electrodes are ∼5.73, ∼26.62, and ∼43.2 Wh kg−1, respectively. From Fig. 10, it can also be observed that the IR drop (while discharging), which in an indication of internal resistance presented by the active electrode material at a constant current, is low in the case of PANi NFs when compared to granular PANi and PANi NTs. This indicates that the electrode constituted by PANi NFs offers less internal resistance, a desired characteristic for a good super capacitor. For convenience, different characteristics of the three PANi nanostructures considered in this study are tabulated in Table 3.
Fig. 10
First charge/discharge curves (measured at a current density of 0.5 A g−1) of electrodes constituted by (a) granular PANi, (b) PANi NTs, and (c) PANi NFs

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: An easy and effective synthesis method to obtain three different nanostructured PANi (namely granular PANi, PANi nanotubes, and PANi nanofibers) has been demonstrated. Properties suitable for the use of these PANi nanostructures as working electrodes in supercapacitors are explicated in correlation with crystallinity, intrinsic oxidation state, doping degree, BET surface area, and ordered porosity pertaining to the nanostructures. PANi nanofibers are found be the best among the three studied PANi nanostructures. Moreover, any uncertainty in the essential factors influencing the electrochemical behavior can now be removed due to the nature of the present study where the three considered nanostructures are obtained using a synthesis route with only miniscule variations.
